coding.Brooks' Law: Adding manpower to a late software project makes it later.
coding.Moore's Law: The number of transistors on integrated circuits doubles approximately every two years.
coding.Conway's Law: Any organization that designs a system (defined broadly) will produce a design whose structure is a copy of the organization's communication structure.
coding.Pareto Principle (80-20 Rule): Roughly 80% of the effects come from 20% of the causes.
coding.YAGNI (You Aren't Gonna Need It): Don't add functionality until it's necessary.
coding.DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself): Every piece of knowledge must have a single, unambiguous, authoritative representation within a system.
coding.KISS (Keep It Simple, Stupid): Most systems work best if they are kept simple rather than made complex.
coding.The Law of Leaky Abstractions: All non-trivial abstractions, to some degree, are leaky.
coding.Linus's Law: Given enough eyeballs, all bugs are shallow.
coding.The Peter Principle: In a hierarchy, every employee tends to rise to their level of incompetence.
coding.Gall's Law: A complex system that works is invariably found to have evolved from a simple system that worked.
coding.Zawinski's Law: Every program attempts to expand until it can read mail.
coding.Metcalfe's Law: The value of a network is proportional to the square of the number of connected users of the system.
coding.Amdahl's Law: The speedup of a program using multiple processors in parallel computing is limited by the time needed for the sequential fraction of the program.
coding.Postel's Law (The Robustness Principle): Be conservative in what you send, be liberal in what you accept.
coding.Parkinson's Law: Work expands so as to fill the time available for its completion.
coding.The Law of Demeter (The Principle of Lea: A module should not know about the innards of the objects it manipulates.
coding.Wirth's Law: Software is getting slower more rapidly than hardware is getting faster.
coding.Tesler's Law (The Law of Conservation of: Every application has an inherent amount of irreducible complexity.
coding.Gallagher's Law: It's easy to solve a problem you understand completely.
coding.Goodhart's Law: When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.
coding.Reed's Law: The utility of large networks, particularly social networks, can scale exponentially with the size of the network.
coding.Metcalfe's Law of Human Behavior: The value of a person's network is proportional to the square of the number of connections they have.

Bible.Genesis Giggle: God creates the world in six days, but I can't even finish my to-do list in a week.
Bible.Ark Adventure: Building an ark to survive a flood sounds like a great DIY project... until you realize you have to fit two of every animal inside.
Bible.Burning Bush Banter: If a bush started talking to me, my first question would definitely be about its skincare routine.
Bible.Ten Commandments Tease: Thou shalt not covet thy neighbor's Wi-Fi password... or maybe just ask politely?
Bible.Red Sea Riddle: Parting the Red Sea sounds impressive, but have you ever tried finding your lost keys in the couch cushions?
Bible.Manna Mystery: Manna from heaven? Sounds delicious... until you realize it's just ancient Israelite granola.
Bible.David vs. Goliath Gag: If David defeated Goliath with a sling and a stone, imagine what he could do with a rocket launcher.
Bible.Tower of Babel Banter: Building a tower to reach the heavens seems ambitious... until you realize you can't even assemble IKEA furniture without instructions.
Bible.Prodigal Son Parody: Returning home after squandering your inheritance on partying? Sounds like a great plot for a reality TV show.
Bible.Jonah Joke: Getting swallowed by a big fish sounds terrifying... until you realize it's the ultimate excuse for missing work.
Bible.Burning Bush Barbecue: Moses: 'Hey God, what's for dinner?' God: 'How about some roasted bush?'
Bible.Job Jive: If Job could endure all those trials and tribulations, he definitely deserves the 'World's Most Patient' award.
Bible.Samson Shenanigans: Samson's source of strength was his hair? No wonder he never skipped a trip to the barber.
Bible.Joseph Jester: Being sold into slavery by your own brothers? Talk about sibling rivalry taken to the extreme.
Bible.Garden of Eden Gag: Eve: 'Adam, why did you eat the forbidden fruit?' Adam: 'I was hungry... and there was a talking snake.'
Bible.Noah's Ark Antics: Noah's Ark: the original 'all aboard the struggle bus' moment.
Bible.Exodus Extravaganza: Forty years in the desert? Sounds like the world's longest camping trip.
Bible.Lazarus Laugh: Lazarus, the original 'I got 99 problems but death ain't one' guy.
Bible.Good Samaritan Comedy: Helping a stranger on the road to Jericho is like giving a thumbs-up to a sketchy Facebook friend request.
Bible.Jonah Jamboree: Jonah: 'I'm not going to Nineveh!' God: 'Hold my fish.'
Bible.Doubting Thomas Drama: Thomas: 'I won't believe Jesus rose from the dead until I see it for myself.' Jesus: 'Challenge accepted.'
Bible.Exodus Exodus: Moses leading the Israelites out of Egypt is like herding cats... if the cats were also complaining about the lack of Wi-Fi.
Bible.Tower of Babel Bash: Building a tower to reach the heavens? Sounds like a classic case of 'aiming high but falling short.'
Bible.Goliath Guffaw: Goliath: 'Am I not a Philistine giant?' David: 'You're a giant pain in the neck.'
Bible.Sermon on the Mount Shenanigans: Blessed are the meme-makers, for they shall inherit the internet.

computer.Blue Screen Blame Game: When in doubt, blame the blue screen of death on gremlins or cosmic rays.
computer.Keyboard Conspiracy: Why do we still have a 'Scroll Lock' key? Does anyone actually use it?
computer.Printer Predicament: Printing: the act of converting perfectly good digital files into random hieroglyphics on paper.
computer.Software Update Sideshow: Updating software is like playing Russian roulette: sometimes it improves things, other times it breaks everything.
computer.Browser Brawl: Choosing a default browser is like choosing a political party: you'll defend your choice to the death, even if you secretly question it.
computer.Caps Lock Catastrophe: WHY IS EVERYONE YELLING? Oh, it's just Caps Lock... again.
computer.USB Upside-Down Dilemma: USBs have only two sides, but I'll still manage to plug them in wrong at least 50% of the time.
computer.Task Manager Tango: Opening Task Manager is like peering into the void: you're never quite sure what you'll find lurking there.
computer.Disk Space Dystopia: Running out of disk space is the digital equivalent of a hoarder's nightmare.
computer.Password Paranoia: My password is so secure, even I can't remember it.
computer.Wi-Fi Woes: The Wi-Fi signal is like the Force: sometimes it's strong, other times it disappears completely without explanation.
computer.Mouse Matador: Chasing the cursor around the screen is my cat's favorite game... and my daily struggle.
computer.Screen Saver Showdown: Choosing a screen saver is like choosing a pet: it says a lot about your personality, but ultimately it's just there to entertain you.
computer.Desktop Disarray: My desktop is like a virtual junk drawer: cluttered, chaotic, and occasionally hiding important things.
computer.Browser Bookmark Bonanza: Bookmarking every interesting article is like collecting Pokemon: gotta catch 'em all!
computer.Autocorrect Apocalypse: Damn you, autocorrect! I didn't mean to tell my boss I'm 'ducking' out early.
computer.Scroll Wheel Shenanigans: Scrolling: the original form of procrastination since the invention of the mouse.
computer.Alt-Tab Tango: Alt-Tabbing between windows is my version of multitasking: pretending to be productive while actually just switching between memes and work.
computer.Desktop Background Dilemma: Changing my desktop background is like redecorating my room: it gives me a false sense of accomplishment without actually doing anything productive.
computer.Notification Nightmare: Notifications: the digital equivalent of that one annoying friend who never stops talking.
computer.File Naming Fiasco: Naming files is like naming children: you want it to be unique, memorable, and not embarrass you in front of your friends.
computer.Emoji Overload: Communicating without emojis is like eating a sandwich without bread: technically possible, but why would you do that?
computer.Webcam Whodunit: Covering my webcam with tape is my way of sticking it to the digital surveillance state... or so I tell myself.
computer.Password Post-it Pandemonium: Writing down passwords on sticky notes: the digital security equivalent of leaving your front door unlocked.
computer.Disk Cleanup Dance: Running disk cleanup is like cleaning out your closet: you'll find a bunch of stuff you forgot you had and wonder why you kept it.

gaming.Respawn Rebellion: In video games, death is just a temporary setback... unless you rage-quit and delete the game.
gaming.Inventory Imagination: Managing inventory in games is like playing Tetris: somehow everything fits perfectly until you find one more item.
gaming.NPC Nonsense: NPCs in games have two modes: overly chatty or completely silent, with no in-between.
gaming.Boss Battle Banter: Boss battles are like relationship arguments: you try different strategies until something works or you throw your controller in frustration.
gaming.Loading Screen Lament: Loading screens are the ultimate test of patience: can you resist the urge to check your phone for three whole seconds?
gaming.Save Point Struggle: Forget 'saving the world'â€”the real struggle is finding a save point before your mom yells at you to come to dinner.
gaming.Speedrun Shenanigans: Speedrunning a game is like mastering a magic trick: impressive to watch, but you have no idea how it's done.
gaming.Microtransaction Madness: Microtransactions: the 'pay-to-win' model that turns games into virtual shopping malls.
gaming.Controller Confusion: Picking up a new game is like learning a new language: you fumble with the controls and hope you don't embarrass yourself in front of NPCs.
gaming.Cutscene Comedy: Cutscenes are like bathroom breaks: you never realize how much you need one until you're forced to sit through a 10-minute dialogue.
gaming.Respawn Routine: Respawning in games is like reincarnation: you come back stronger, wiser, and ready to make the same mistakes all over again.
gaming.Quest Quandary: Quests in games are like errands: you promise yourself it'll be quick, but three hours later you're still searching for that elusive item.
gaming.Loot Box Lunacy: Opening loot boxes is like scratching lottery tickets: most of the time you get nothing, but that one time you win feels oh-so-good.
gaming.Inventory Intimidation: Inventory management in games is like a game in itself: 'How many potions can I carry before encumbrance becomes a problem?'
gaming.Stealth Stumble: Playing a stealth game is like trying to tiptoe through a minefield... with an elephant.
gaming.Achievement Anecdote: Achievements in games are like participation trophies: they make you feel accomplished even if all you did was press 'Start'.
gaming.Respawn Reflection: Respawning teaches you valuable life lessons: sometimes you fail, respawn, and fail again until you get it right.
gaming.Boss Battle Blunder: Boss battles are like a dance: you memorize the steps, anticipate the moves, and hope you don't trip over your own feet (or keyboard).
gaming.Loading Screen Limbo: Loading screens are the ultimate test of creativity: can you come up with new ways to entertain yourself for 30 seconds?
gaming.Controller Connection Conundrum: Trying to connect a new controller is like solving a Rubik's Cube blindfolded: frustrating, confusing, and occasionally rewarding.
gaming.Save Point Sarcasm: Finding a save point after a marathon gaming session is like finding an oasis in the desert: a moment of relief in an endless journey.
gaming.Skill Tree Skepticism: Skill trees in games are like buffet menus: you want to try everything, but you know you'll end up sticking with the same few options.
gaming.Cutscene Catastrophe: Skipping cutscenes is like speed-reading a novel: you miss the details, but you get to the good part faster.
gaming.Respawn Rant: Respawning is like hitting the 'undo' button on life: you wish it were that easy in real life.
